channel.title: Interface Handler help
channel.description:
I'm starting back on 'Project Anfernio' after taking a break on it (Haven't worked on it since late Semptember! ;))
I made a handler for Interfaces, but I always get this error:
[code]attInterface(client) in Interfaces cannot be applied to ()[/code]
Tried everything that's come to my mind.
Here's the code I'm using: [code]case 34142: Interfaces.attInterface(); break;[/code]

item.title: Interface Handler help
item.dc:creator: @Anfernio Anfernio
item.description:
@Anfernio wrote:

Resolved!

Major thanks to The Soul!

Read full topic

item.title: Interface Handler help
item.dc:creator: @the_soul The Soul
item.description:
@the_soul wrote:

[quote=“Anfernio, post:14, topic:325032”][quote author=The Soul link=topic=421380.msg3094789#msg3094789 date=1263176565]
Oh, in that case, just do:

Interfaces.attInterface(client);

[/quote]

Tried that before, you know the drill, haha.

Getting bored of editing the other info shit out.

.\Source\clickingMost.java:167: cannot find symbol symbol : variable client location: class clickingMost Interfaces.attInterface(client); ^ .\Source\clickingMost.java:167: non-static method attInterface(client) cannot be referenced from a static context Interfaces.attInterface(client); ^ 2 errors Press any key to continue . . .[/quote]

You have to make the attInterface() method static.

Read full topic

item.title: Interface Handler help
item.dc:creator: @Anfernio Anfernio
item.description:
@Anfernio wrote:

[quote=“The Soul, post:13, topic:325032”]Oh, in that case, just do:

Interfaces.attInterface(client);

Tried that before, you know the drill, haha.

Getting bored of editing the other info shit out.

.\Source\clickingMost.java:167: cannot find symbol symbol : variable client location: class clickingMost Interfaces.attInterface(client); ^ .\Source\clickingMost.java:167: non-static method attInterface(client) cannot be referenced from a static context Interfaces.attInterface(client); ^ 2 errors Press any key to continue . . .

Read full topic

item.title: Interface Handler help
item.dc:creator: @the_soul The Soul
item.description:
@the_soul wrote:

[quote=“Anfernio, post:12, topic:325032”][quote author=The Soul link=topic=421380.msg3094774#msg3094774 date=1263175973]

Where is its invokation though?

Whatever the fuck that big word means 

Interfaces.attInterface(this);

That’s a method invokation.

Oh.

case 34142: Interfaces.attInterface(this); break;

I know, but what class?
[/quote]

clickingMost, lol.[/quote]

Oh, in that case, just do:

Interfaces.attInterface(client);

Read full topic

item.title: Interface Handler help
item.dc:creator: @the_soul The Soul
item.description:
@the_soul wrote:

[quote=“Anfernio, post:5, topic:325032”][quote author=The Soul link=topic=421380.msg3094733#msg3094733 date=1263174062]

Interfaces.attInterface(this);

Your method had a parameter variable.

Thanks for replying The Soul.

But, new error now.

attInterface(client) in Interfaces cannot be applied to (clickingMost)

Post the method and tell me what class its invokation is in.
[/quote]

Method:

public void attInterface(client c) { c.sendFrame126("@dre@Attack Skill Menu", 8716); for(int i = 0;i<31;i++) { item[i] = 0; } item[0] = 1321; item[1] = 1325; item[2] = 1329; item[3] = 1331; item[4] = 1333; item[5] = 4587; item[6] = 4755; item[7] = 35; item[8] = 2677; for(int i = 8720;i<8799;i++) { c.sendFrame126("",i); } c.sendFrame126("1",8720); c.sendFrame126("Bronze/Iron weapons",8760); c.sendFrame126("5",8721); c.sendFrame126("Steel weapons", 8761); c.sendFrame126("20",8722); c.sendFrame126("Mithril weapons",8762); c.sendFrame126("30",8723); c.sendFrame126("Adamant weapons", 8763); c.sendFrame126("40",8724); c.sendFrame126("Rune weapons", 8764); c.sendFrame126("60",8725); c.sendFrame126("Dragon weapons",8765); c.sendFrame126("70",8726); c.sendFrame126("Barrow weapons", 8766); c.sendFrame126("75",8727); c.sendFrame126("Godswords", 8767); c.sendFrame126("",8849);// members only skill c.sendFrame126("",8827);//steel c.sendFrame126("",8837);//mithril c.sendFrame126("99", 8728); c.sendFrame126("Attack Skillcape", 8768); c.sendFrame126("Theiving",8840); c.sendFrame126("Thieving",8843); c.sendFrame126("Attack",8846); // first option c.sendFrame126("Strength",8823); c.sendFrame126("Defence",8824); c.sendFrame126("",8859); c.sendFrame126("",8862); c.sendFrame126("",8865); c.sendFrame126("",15303); c.sendFrame126("",15306); c.sendFrame126("",15309); c.sendSkillInterface(item); c.showInterface(8714); }

The class it’s in is class Interfaces, which is where I’m handling it.[/quote]

Where is its invokation though?

Read full topic

item.title: Interface Handler help
item.dc:creator: @Anfernio Anfernio
item.description:
@Anfernio wrote:

[quote=“The Soul, post:4, topic:325032”][quote author=Anfernio link=topic=421380.msg3094730#msg3094730 date=1263173984]

Interfaces.attInterface(this);

Your method had a parameter variable.

Thanks for replying The Soul.

But, new error now.

attInterface(client) in Interfaces cannot be applied to (clickingMost)

[/quote]

Post the method and tell me what class its invokation is in.[/quote]

Method:

public void attInterface(client c) { c.sendFrame126("@dre@Attack Skill Menu", 8716); for(int i = 0;i<31;i++) { item[i] = 0; } item[0] = 1321; item[1] = 1325; item[2] = 1329; item[3] = 1331; item[4] = 1333; item[5] = 4587; item[6] = 4755; item[7] = 35; item[8] = 2677; for(int i = 8720;i<8799;i++) { c.sendFrame126("",i); } c.sendFrame126("1",8720); c.sendFrame126("Bronze/Iron weapons",8760); c.sendFrame126("5",8721); c.sendFrame126("Steel weapons", 8761); c.sendFrame126("20",8722); c.sendFrame126("Mithril weapons",8762); c.sendFrame126("30",8723); c.sendFrame126("Adamant weapons", 8763); c.sendFrame126("40",8724); c.sendFrame126("Rune weapons", 8764); c.sendFrame126("60",8725); c.sendFrame126("Dragon weapons",8765); c.sendFrame126("70",8726); c.sendFrame126("Barrow weapons", 8766); c.sendFrame126("75",8727); c.sendFrame126("Godswords", 8767); c.sendFrame126("",8849);// members only skill c.sendFrame126("",8827);//steel c.sendFrame126("",8837);//mithril c.sendFrame126("99", 8728); c.sendFrame126("Attack Skillcape", 8768); c.sendFrame126("Theiving",8840); c.sendFrame126("Thieving",8843); c.sendFrame126("Attack",8846); // first option c.sendFrame126("Strength",8823); c.sendFrame126("Defence",8824); c.sendFrame126("",8859); c.sendFrame126("",8862); c.sendFrame126("",8865); c.sendFrame126("",15303); c.sendFrame126("",15306); c.sendFrame126("",15309); c.sendSkillInterface(item); c.showInterface(8714); }

The class it’s in is class Interfaces, which is where I’m handling it.
